poem:
### Decoding Earth

In Belfast's storied halls, where past whispers blend with now,  
An accidental journey, from scoops of cream to ancient silt.  
Dreams of sweetcones melt into peat and pollen's silent vow,  
Where time's trembling voice speaks through layers expertly built.  
Ice-cream dreams dissolve, in icy depths we plough,  
Uncovering secrets to shield our fragile Earth somehow.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "How Queen’s University Belfast became a global hub for decoding Earth’s past – and protecting its future The interdisciplinary approach at Queen’s University Belfast has helped it attract some of the finest minds to fight critical climate and environmental threats.Take Prof Maarten Blaauw. He fell into palaeoecology, the ecology of subfossil animals and plants, almost by accident. As a boy, he wanted to be an ice-cream seller but just one afternoon in the job convinced". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
